Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) \.raw_text: Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) – Establishing a material change in circumstances for custody modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) \.proposition: Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) – Establishing a material change in circumstances for custody modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) \.support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in the context of existing joint physical and legal custody. The court’s analysis focuses on what “cause shown” means (i.e., a best-interests standard) when a joint custodian seeks to relocate, not on what constitutes a “material change in circumstances” warranting modification of custody. Although the opinion quotes ALI Principles mentioning relocation as a substantial change, Mason itself does not adopt or apply a ‘material change in circumstances’ test or framework for custody modification; its holding is about the substantive best-interests standard for removal with joint custody, not about establishing or defining a threshold material change requirement.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) \.relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]…’
… ALI Principles… support the view that where ‘neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility,’ the effect of the relocation on the child is a ‘relevant factor[]’ in determining the child’s best interests.”

Annunziata v. Annunziata, 457 Mass. 591.raw_text: Annunziata v. Annunziata, 457 Mass. 591 (2010) – Importance of parental cooperation and communication in custody cases.
Annunziata v. Annunziata, 457 Mass. 591.proposition: Annunziata v. Annunziata, 457 Mass. 591 (2010) – Importance of parental cooperation and communication in custody cases.
Annunziata v. Annunziata, 457 Mass. 591.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Annunziata v. Annunziata; it is a Massachusetts criminal case involving Commonwealth v. Durand (a murder prosecution). The decision focuses on confrontation rights, admissibility of expert and hearsay evidence, voluntariness of statements, and related criminal procedure issues. It does not address child custody, parental cooperation, or communication between parents, so it cannot support a proposition about the importance of parental cooperation and communication in custody cases.
Annunziata v. Annunziata, 457 Mass. 591.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that the testimony concerning the factual contents of the autopsy report prepared by a nontestifying medical examiner violated the defendant’s constitutional right of confrontation, see Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 53-54 (2004); Commonwealth v. Gonsalves, 445 Mass. 1, 5-10 (2005), cert. denied, 548 U.S. 926 (2006), and that in the circumstances of this case the error was not harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. Accordingly, we reverse the defendant’s conviction of murder.

Taylor v. Taylor, 440 Mass. 413 (2003) \.raw_text: Taylor v. Taylor, 440 Mass. 413 (2003) – Consideration of children's welfare in custody matters.
Taylor v. Taylor, 440 Mass. 413 (2003) \.proposition: Taylor v. Taylor, 440 Mass. 413 (2003) – Consideration of children's welfare in custody matters.
Taylor v. Taylor, 440 Mass. 413 (2003) \.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Taylor v. Taylor, 440 Mass. 413 (2003), but a criminal case involving a defendant named Koumaris and issues of Miranda, voir dire of jurors, and alleged prosecutorial vouching. It does not concern child custody or the consideration of children’s welfare in custody determinations. Therefore, this opinion does not support the proposition about Taylor v. Taylor and children’s welfare in custody matters.
Taylor v. Taylor, 440 Mass. 413 (2003) \.relevant_excerpt: "On January 9, 2002, the defendant, Steven J. Koumaris, was convicted of a 1975 felony-murder in the first degree with armed robbery as the predicate felony... The defendant appeals arguing that it was error for the Superior Court judge... to deny his motion to suppress confessions... and to refuse to conduct a voir dire of the jury... He also argues that the prosecutor vouched for the veracity of a Commonwealth witness in closing argument..."

Ross v. Ross, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (200.raw_text: Ross v. Ross, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (2007) – Impact of parental actions on the child's well-being in custody proceedings.
Ross v. Ross, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (200.proposition: Ross v. Ross, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (2007) – Impact of parental actions on the child's well-being in custody proceedings.
Ross v. Ross, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (200.case_name: Andrews v. Division of Medical Assistance
Ross v. Ross, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (200.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns Medicaid/MassHealth eligibility and whether payments to a daughter and son‑in‑law for renovating an elder’s house could be deducted from the elder’s estate. The court analyzes administrative rules on transfers of assets and the presumption that family-provided services are gratuitous, not child custody or the impact of parental actions on a child’s well-being. It therefore does not address or establish any principle about custody proceedings or parental conduct affecting a child, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Ross v. Ross, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (200.relevant_excerpt: “At issue in this case is whether money that was paid by Marion Andrews (plaintiff) to her daughter and son-in-law (Tekulas) on account of labor they performed to renovate her house properly could be deducted from her estate to determine her eligibility for assistance. We conclude that valid agency rules reasonably were applied to deny the deduction, and eligibility for assistance properly was determined.”

Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 70 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 28 (2007) – Factors considered in determining modification of custody orders.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 70 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 28 (2007) – Factors considered in determining modification of custody orders.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 70 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the civil commitment of a sexually dangerous person under G.L. c. 123A and discusses statutory timing, use of examiners, jury waiver, and related procedural/constitutional issues. It does not involve child custody, parenting plans, or modification of custody orders, nor does it set out factors for modifying custody. Therefore it does not support the proposition claimed about custody modification factors.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 70 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: The defendant appeals his commitment as a sexually dangerous person pursuant to G. L. c. 123A. He asserts an abundance of errors, primary among them violations of the time periods prescribed by §§ 13(a) and 14(a) of that statute, his examination by more than the two qualified examiners he claims are authorized by § 13(a), and ineffective assistance of counsel. We deal with each claim in turn.
